update.description:
Upscale all icons to at least 32x32.

This means that on high DPI displays, labscript suite apps can have icons that are not tiny.

Custom icons were upscaled by re-exporting source svgs at higher resolution.

Fugue icons upscaled to 32x32 by simple pixel doubling. This way we are not
relying on Qt to scale the icons (which was another option), which uses
interpolation that looks even worse considering icons are pixel-art.

The script to perform the upscaling is included in the repository, and
the original 16x16 icons kept.

This is a decent stop-gap to look OK on high DPI screens until an icon set as
comprehensive as fugue exists at higher resolution (I cannot find anything
comparable at the moment).

Including icons in multiple sizes was an option I explored, but it does not work
well with Qt designer - it does not choose the correct icon size from .ico
files, and there isn't any other way to include multiple sizes without having to specify which one to use. It seems that including an excessively large icon and letting Qt downscale is the
current best practice (unfortunately). I would have liked to upscale the icons
using clever pixel-art scaling filters, but then they look terrible when
Qt *downscales* them for a standard DPI screen. So scaling by pixel doubling
is the lesser evil for the moment.

It's not the prettiest, but I think this should do us icon-wise until 8k screens start catching on.

content.raw:
Gah, this is no good. Setting a pixmap in a label does not get scaled down since it is not an ‘icon’:

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/Rg5nLg/images/1636310498-Screenshot_from_2019-03-29_15-26-16.png)
So this approach is bogus. Have to rethink.

The only other thing I can think of is to build both scaled and unscaled versions of the icon resource files, then at import time, if qtutils detects that it’s on a high DPI screen, it loads the scaled ones, otherwise it loads the unscaled ones. This is not ideal because then what if you have mixed DPI screens? I don’t know what Qt does in this case presently \(Guessing it doesn’t handle it well\), but it sucks if we were to force a particular icon size and then Qt actually did work with mixed DPI \(if not now, in the future\). 

Maybe the right thing to do is just turn on the DPI scaling option where Qt will scale everything up. It’s just icons look terrible and blurry in that case.

Will think a little more about this.

‌

So this approach is bogus. Have to rethink.

The only other thing I can think of is to build both scaled and unscaled versions of the icon resource files, then at import time, if qtutils detects that it’s on a high DPI screen, it loads the scaled ones, otherwise it loads the unscaled ones. This is not ideal because then what if you have mixed DPI screens? I don’t know what Qt does in this case presently (Guessing it doesn’t handle it well), but it sucks if we were to force a particular icon size and then Qt actually did work with mixed DPI (if not now, in the future).

Maybe the right thing to do is just turn on the DPI scaling option where Qt will scale everything up. It’s just icons look terrible and blurry in that case.

Will think a little more about this.
